editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Blurt master-constable. Or the Spaniards night-walk. As it hath been sundry times privately acted by the children of Paul's.

quote.l: Frond comas vincti coenant, et carmina dictant.

div.p: London, printed for Henry Rockytt, and are to be sold at the long shop under s. Mildred's church in the poultry. 1602.

div.head: Blurt master Constable.
div.stage: Enter Camillo with Violetta, Hipolito, Baptista, Bentivolio, and Virgilio, as returning from war, every one with a glove in his hat, ladies with them, Doyt and dandiprat.

sp.speaker: Hipol
sp.p: I marry sir, the only rising up in arms, is in the arms of a woman: peace (I say still) is your only paradise, when every Adam may have his Christmas Eve: and you take me lying any more by the cold sides of a brazen-face field-piece unless I have such a down pillow under me, I'll give you leave to knock up both my golls in my father's hall, and hang hats upon these tenpenny nails.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And yet brother, when with the sharpest hooks of my wit I laboured to pull you from the wars, you broke loose, like a horse that knew his own strength, and vowed, nothing but a man of war should back you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I have been backed since and almost unbacked too.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And swore that honour was never died in grain, till it was dipped in the colours of the field.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
I am a new man sister, and now cry a pox a that honour, that must have none but barber-surgeons to wait upon't, and a band of poor straggling rascals, that every twinkling of an eye, forfeit their legs and arms into the lords hands wenches by Mars his sweaty buff jerkin, (For now all my 〈◊〉 must smell a the soldado) I have seen more men's head 〈◊〉 up
and down like footballs at a breakfast, after the hungry cannons had picked them; than are maidenheads in Venice: and more legs of men served in at a dinner, than ever I shall see legs of capons in one platter whilst I live.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: Perhaps all those were capons legs you did see.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Nay mistress I'll witness against you for some of them.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.p: I do not think for all this, that my brother stood to it so lustily as he makes his brags for.

sp.speaker: 3 lady.
sp.l: No, no, these great talkers are never great doers.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: Faith brother how many did you kill for your share?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Not so many as thou hast done with that villainous eye by a thousand.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I thought so much that's just none.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis not a soldier's glory to tell how many lives he has ended, but how many he has saved: in both which honours the noble Hipolito had most excellent possession. Believe it my fair mistress, though many men in a battle have done more, your brother in this equalled him who did most: he went from you a worthy gentleman, he brings with him that title that makes a gentleman most worthy; the name of a soldier, which how well and how soon he hath earned, would in me seem glorious to rehearse, in you to hear: but because his own ear dwells so near my voice, I will play the ill neighbour, and cease to speak well of him.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: An argument that either you dare not, or love not to flatter.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No more than I dare or love to do wrong; yet to make a chronicle of my friends nobly-acted deeds, would stand as far from flattery in me, as cowardice did from him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: 'Sfoot if all the wit in this company have nothing to set itself about, but to run division upon me, why then e'en burn off mine ears indeed, but my little mermaids, signior Camillo does this, that I now might describe the ninivitical motion of the whole battle, and so tell what he has done: and come, shall I begin?

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: O for beauty's love, a good motion.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But I can tell you one thing, I shall make your hair stand up an end at some things.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.p: Prithee good brother soldier keep the peace, our hair stand an end? pity a my heart, the next end would be of our wits: we hang out a white flag most terrible Tamberlaine, and beg mercy; come, come, let us neither have your ninivitical motions nor your swaggering battles: why my lord Camillo, you invited me hither to a banquet, not to the ballad of a pitched field.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And here it stands bright mistress, sweetly attending what doom your lips willay upon it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I marry sir, let our teeth describe this motion.

sp.speaker: 2 lady.
sp.p: We shall never describe it well, for fumbling i'th mouth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have a trick to make us understand one another and we fumble never so —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Meddle not with his tricks sweet heart; under pardon my lord, though I am your guest, I'll bestow myself, sit dear beauties: for the men, let them take up places themselves; I prithee brother fighter sit, and talk of any subject, but this langling law at arms.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The law at logs then.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Will you be so lusty? no nor legs neither, we'll have them tied up too, since you are among ladies: gallants, handle those things only that are fit for ladies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Agreed so that we go not out of the compass of those things that are fit for lords.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Be't so, what's the theme then?

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: Beauty, that fits us best.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And of beauty what tongue would not speak the best? since it is the jewel that hangs upon the brow of heaven, the best colour that can be laid upon the cheek of earth: beauty makes men gods immortal, by making mortal men to live ever in love. (For love.

sp.speaker: 2 lady.
sp.l: Ever ▪ not so, I have heard that some men have died

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p:
So have I, but I could never see't: I'd ride forty miles
to follow such a fellow to church, and would make more of a sprig of rosemary at his burial, than of a gilded bride-branch at mine own wedding.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.l: Take you such delight in men that die for love?

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.p: Not in the men nor in the death, but in the deed; troth I think he is not a sound man that will die for a woman, and yet I would never love a man soundly, that would not knock at death's door for my love.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I'd knock as long as I thought good, but have my brains knocked out when I entered, if I were he.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What Venetian gentleman was there; that having this in his burgonet, did not (To prove his head worthy of the honour) do more than defy death to the very face? trust us ladies, our signiory stands bound in greater sums of thanks to your beauties for victory, than to our valour: my dear Violetta one kiss to this picture of your whitest hand, when I was even faint, (With giving and receiving the dole of war)
sp.l: Set a new edge on my sword: in so much that,
I singled out a gallant spirit of France,
And charged him with my lance in full career,
And after rich exchange of noble courage,
(The space of a good hour on either side)
At last crying, now for Violetta's honour,
I vanquished him, and him (Dismounted) took
Not to myself, but prisoner to my love.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I have heard much praise of that French gallant, good my lord, bring him acquainted with our eyes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will, go boy fetch noble Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Will your French prisoner drink well? or else cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O no he cannot brook it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: The pox he can, 'slight methinks a French man should have a good courage to wine, for many of them be exceeding hot fiery whoresons, and resolute as Hector, and as valiant as Troilus; then come off and on bravely and lie by it, and sweat fort too, upon a good and a military advantage.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Prithee have done here comes the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My lord Camillo, is this the gentleman,
Whose valour, by your valour is subdued?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It is fair lady, and I yield him up,
To be your beauty's worthy prisoner:
Lord Fontinell, think your captivity
Happy in this, she that hath conquered me,
Receives my conquest, as my love's fair fee.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Fair stranger droop not, since the chance of wars
Brings to the soldier death, restraint, or scars.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Lady, I know the fortune of the field,
Is death with honour, or with shame to yield,
As I have done.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: In that no scandal lies,
Who dies when he may live, he doubly dies.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: My reputation's lost.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: Nay that's not so,
You flee not but were vanquished by your foe,
The eye of war respects not you nor him,
It is our fate will have us lose or win,
You will disdain if I you prisoner call?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: No, but rejoice, since I am beauty's thrall.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Enough of this, come wenches shake your heels.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Music advance thee on thy golden wing,
And dance division from sweet string to string.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Camillo I shall curb thy tyranny,
In making me that lady's prisoner:
She has an angel's body, but within't,
Her coy heart says there lies a heart of flint,
Such beauty be my jailor? A heavenly hell!
The darkest dungeon, which spite can devise,
To throw this carcase in, her glorious eyes
Can make as lightsome, as the fairest chamber
In Paris Louvre: come captivity,
And chain me to her looks; how am I tossed?
Being twice in mind, as twice in body lost.
sp.stage: Whilst Fontinell speaks, they dance a strain, Violetta on a sudden breaks off, the rest stand talking.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not the measure out fair mistress?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: No, fair servant, not the measure out, I have on the sudden a foolish desire to be out of the measure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What breeds that desire?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay I hope it is no breeding matter, tush, tush, by my maidenhead I will not, the music likes me not, and I have a shoe wrings me to'th heart; besides I have a woman's reason, I will not dance, because I will not dance: prithee dear hero take my prisoner there into the measure; fie I cannot abide to see a man sad nor idle, I'll be out once, as the music is (In mine care)

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Lady, bid him whose heart no sorrow feels,
Tickle the rushes with his wanton heels,
I have too much lead at mine.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: I'll make it light.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: By a nimble dance.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: You hit it right.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: Your keeper bids you dance.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Then I obey,
My heart I feel grows light, it melts away.
sp.stage: They dance, Violetta stands by marking Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In troth a very pretty French man, the carriage of his body likes me well; so does his footing so does his face, so does his eye above his face, so does himself, above all that can be above himself.
sp.l: Camillo thou hast played a foolish part,
Thy prisoner makes a slave of thy love's heart.
sp.p:
Shall Camillo then sing willow, willow, willow? not for the world: no, no, my French prisoner; I will use thee Cupid knows how, and teach thee to fall into the hands of a woman: if I do not
feed thee with fair looks, ne'er let me live: if thou gettest out of my fingers till I have thy very heart, ne'er let me love; nothing but thy life shall serve my turn, and how otherwise I'll plague thee, monsieur you and I'll deal, only this, because I'll be sure he shall not start, I'll lock him in a little low room besides himself, where his wanton eye shall see neither sun nor moon: so, the dance is done, and my heart has done her worst, made me in love: farewell my lord, I have much haste, you have many thanks, I am angered a little, but am greatly pleased: if you wonder that I take this strange leave; excuse it thus, that women are strange fools, and will take any thing.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Tricks: tricks? kerry merry buff; how now lad, in a trance?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Strange farewell: after, dear Hippolito,
Oh what a maze is love of joy and woe!

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Strange frenzy; after wretched Fontinell,
O what a heaven is love! o what a hell!
sp.stage: Enter Lazarillo melancholy, and Pilcher his boy.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Boy, I am melancholy because I burn.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: And I am melancholy because I am a cold.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I pine away with the desire of flesh.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: It's neither flesh nor fish that I pine for, but for both.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Pilcher, Cupid hath got me a stomach, and I long for laced mutton.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Plain mutton without a lace would serve me.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: For as your tame monkey is your only best, and most only beast to your Spanish lady: or, as your tobacco is your only smoker away of rheum, and all other rheumatic diseases: or as your Irish louse does bite most naturally fourteen weeks, after the change of your saffron seamed shirt or, as the commodities which are sent out of the Low-countries (And put in vessels called mother Cornelius dry-fats) are most common in France: so it pleaseth the destinies, that I should thirst to drink out of a most sweet Italian vessel, being a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: What vessel is that signiort

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A woman Pilcher, the moist handed madonna Imperia, a most rare and divine creature.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: A most rascally damned courtesan.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Boy, hast thou foraged the country for a new lodging? for I have sworn to lay my bones in this city of Venice.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Any man that sees us will swear that we shall both lay our bones, and nothing but bones, and we stalk here longer; they tell me signior, I must go to the constable, and he is to see you lodged.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Inquire for that busy-member of the chitty.
sp.stage: Enter Doyt and Dandyprat passing over.

sp.speaker: Pilc.
sp.p: I will, and here come a leash of informers: save you plump youths.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: And thee my lean stripling.

sp.speaker: Pilc.
sp.l: Which is the constable's house?

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: That at the sign of the brown bill.

sp.speaker: Pilch.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Why, and farewell; the rogue's made of piecrust he's so short.

sp.speaker: Pilch.
sp.l: The officious gentleman inherits here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Knock, or enter, and let thy voice pull him out by the ears.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.p: 'Slid dandiprat, this is the Spanish curtal that in the last battle, fled twenty miles ere he looked behind him.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Doyt, he did the wiser: but sirrah, this block shall be a rare threshold for us to whet our wits upon; come, let's about our business, and if here we find him at our return, he shall find us this month in knavery.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: What ho, nobody speaks, where dwells the constable?
sp.stage: Enter Blurt and Slubber the beadle.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Here dwells the constable; call assistance, give them my full charge, raze (If you see cause) now sir, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Pilc.
sp.l: Follower to that spanish-leather gentleman.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: And what are you sir, that cry out upon me? look to his tools. What are are you sir? speak, what are you? I charge you what are you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Most clear mirror of magistrates, I am a servitor to God Mars.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: For your serving of God I am not to meddle, why do you raze me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I desire to have a wide room in your favour: sweet blood, cast away your name upon me; for I neither know you by your face, nor by your voice

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: It may be so sir; I have two voices in any company: one, as I am master Constable: another, as I am Blurt: and the third, as I am Blurt master Constable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I understand, you are a mighty pillar or post in the city.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: I am a poor post, but not to stand at every man's door, without my bench of billmen: I am (For a better) the Duke's own image and charge you in his name to obey me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I do so.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: I am to stand sir in any bawdy house, or sink of wickedness: I am the Duke's own grace, and in any fray or resurrection, am to bestir my stumps as well as he; I charge you know

sp.speaker: Slub.
sp.l: Turn the arms to him. (This staff.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Upon this may I lean and no man say black's mine eye

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Who so ever says you have a black eye, is a camooche. most great Blurt; I do unpent-house the roof of my carcase and touch the knee of thy office in Spanish compliment, I desire to sojourn in your chitty.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Sir, sir, for fault of a better, I am to charge you, not to keep a soldiering in our city without a precept: besides, by my office I am to search and examine you: have you the Duke's hand to pass? (Fingers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Signior no, I have the general's hand at large, and all his

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Except it be for the general good of the commonwealth, the general cannot lead you up and down our city.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I have the general's hand to pass through the world at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Blurt.
sp.p: At your pleasure? that's rare; then roly-poly , our wives shall lie at your command: your general has no such authority in my precinct, and therefore I charge you pass no further.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I tell thee, I will pass through the world, thou little morsel of justice, and eat twenty such as thou art.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Sir, sir, you shall find Venice out of the world: I'll tickle you for that.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I will pass through the world, as Alexander Magnus did, to conquer.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: As Alexander of saint Magnus did? that's another matter, you might have informed this at the first, and you never needed to have come to your answer: let me see your pass, if it be not the Duke's hand, I'll tickle you for all this: quickly I pray ▪ this staff is to walk in other places.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: There it is.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Slubber, read it over.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Read it yourself, what bezonian is that?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: This is my clerk sir, he has been clerk to a good many bonds and bills of mine, I keep him only to read, for I cannot, my office will not let me.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Why do you put on your spectacles then?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: To see that he read right: how now slubber, is't the Duke's hand? I'll tickle him else.

sp.speaker: Slu.
sp.l: Mastis not like his hand.

sp.speaker: Blurt.
sp.p: Look well, the Duke has a wart on the back of his hand.

sp.speaker: Slub.
sp.p: Here's none on my word master Constable, but a little blot.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Blot? let's see let's see; ho that stands for the wart, do you see the trick of that? Stay stay, is there not a little prick in the hand for the Duke's hand had a prick in't when I was with him, with opening oysters.

sp.speaker: Slu.
sp.l: Yes mass here's one, besides 'tis a goodly great long hand.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: So has the Duke a goodly huge hand, I have shaken him by it, (God forgive me) ten thousand times: he must pass like Alexander of saint Magnus; well sir, ('tis your duty to stand bare) the Duke has sent his fist to me, and I were a Jew if I should shrink for it; I obey, you must pass, but pray take heed with what dice you pass, I mean what company, for Sathan is most busy, where he finds one like himself ▪ your name sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Lazarillo de Tormes in Castille, cozen germane to the adolantado of Spain.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Are you so sir? God's blessing on your heart: your name again sir, if it be not too tedious for you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Lazarillo de Tormes in Castille, cousin-german to the Spanish adolantado.

sp.speaker: Slub.
sp.l: I warrant he's a great man in his own country.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Has a good name, slubber set it down: write, Lazarus in torment at the castle, and a cozening German, at the sign of the palantido diddle in Spain: so sir you are engrossed, you must give my officer a groat it's nothing to me signior.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will cancel when it comes to a sum.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Well sir, well he shall give you an item for't, make a bill and he'll tear it he says.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Most admirable Blurt, I am a man of war and profess fighting.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: I charge you in the Duke's name keep the peace.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By your sweet favour most dear Blurt, you charge too fast, I am a hanger on upon Mars, and have a few crowns.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Two: his own and mine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And desire you to point out a fair lodging for me and my train.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: 'Tis my office signior to take men up a nights, but if you will, my maids shall take you up a mornings, since you profess fighting; I will commit you signior to mine own house, but will you pitch and pay, or will your worship run —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I scorn to run from the face of Thamer Cham.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Then sir, you mean not to run?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Signior no.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Bear witness slubber, that his answer is signior no: so now if he runs upon the score, I have him straight upon signior no; this is my house signior, enter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: March excellent Blurt: attend pilchard.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Upon your trencher signior, most hungerly.

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.l: Now sirrah where's thy master?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The constable has pressed him.

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.l: What, for a soldier?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Ay, for a soldier; but ere he'll go, I think indeed, he and I together shall press the constable.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: No matter, squeeze him, and leave no more liquor in him, than in a dried neat's tongue: sirrah thin-gut, what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: My name? you chops, why I am of the blood of the pilchers.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Nay 'sfoot, if one should kill thee, he could not be hanged for't, for he would shed no blood, there's none in thee: pilchard? thou'rt a most pitiful dried one.

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.p: I wonder thy master does not slice thee, and swallow thee for an anchoves.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: He wants wine boy to swallow me down, for he wants money to swallow down wine: but farewell, I must dog my master.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: As long as thou dog'st a Spaniard, thou'lt ne'er be fatter; but stay, our haste is as great as thine, yet to endear ourselves into thy lean acquaintance cry Rivo hogh, laugh and be fat, and for joy that we are met we'll meet and be merry, sing:

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I'll make a shift to squeak.

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: And I, for my profession is to shift as well as you, hem:

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: What meat eats the Spaniard?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Dried pilchers and poor John:

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Alas thou art almost marred.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: My cheeks are fallen and gone.

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: Wouldst thou not leap at a piece of meat?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: O how my teeth do water, I could eat
For the heavens; my flesh is almost gone
With eating of pilchard and poor John.
sp.stage: Enter Fontenell from tennis, and True-penny with him.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: Am I so happy then?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.l: Nay sweet monsieur.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: O, boy thou hast new winged my captived soul,
Now to my fortune all the fates may yield,
For I have won where first I lost the field.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why sir, did my mistress prick you with the Spanish needle of her love, before I summoned you (From her) to this parley?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Doubts thou that boy ▪

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Of mine honesty I doubt extremely, for I cannot see the little god's tokens upon you: there is as much difference between you and a lover, as between a cuckold and a unicorn.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Why boy?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: For you do not wear a pair of ruffled, frowning, ungartered stockings, like a gallant that hides his small timbered legs, with a quail-pipe boot: your hose stands upon too many points, and are not troubled with that falling sickness, which follows pale, meager, miserable, melancholy lovers: your hands are not groping continually.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Where my little observer?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
In your greasy pocket sir, like one that wants a cloak for the rain, and yet is still weather-beaten: your hat nor head are not of the true heigh-ho-block, for it should be broad brimmed, limber, like the skin of a white pudding when the meat is out: the facing fatty: the felt dusty,
and not entered into any band, but your hat is of the nature of a loose, light, heavy-swelling wench, too straight laced: I tell you monsieur, a lover should be all loose from the sole of the foot rising upward; and from the bases, or confines of the slop, falling downwards: if you were in my mistress's chamber, you should find othergates privy signs of love hanging out there.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Have your little eyes watched so narrowly?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O sir, a page must have a cat's eye, a spaniel's leg, a whore's tongue (A little tasting of the cog) a catchpole's hand, what he gripes is his own; and a little little bawdy.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Fair Violetta I will wear thy love,
Like this French order, near unto my heart,
Via for fate, fortune, lo this is all,
At grief's rebound I'll mount, although I fall.
sp.stage: Enter Camillo and Hipolito from tennis, Doyt and Dandeprat with their cloaks and rapiers.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now by saint mark he's a most treacherous villain,
Dare the base Frenchman's eye gaze on my love?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay sweet rogue, why wouldst thou make his face a vizard, to have two loopholes only? when he comes to a good face, may he not do with his eyes what he will: 'sfoot if I were as he, I'd pull them out, and if I wist they would anger thee.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.l: Thou add'st heat to my rage, away, stand back,
Dishonoured slave, more treacherous than base,
This is the instance of my scorned disgrace.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Thou ill advised italian whence proceeds
This sudden fury?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Villain from thee.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Hercules stand between them.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Villain by my blood;
I am as free born as your Venice Duke.
Villain, saint Dennis and my life to boot,
Thy lips shall kiss this pavement or my foot.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Your foot with a pox? I hope you're no Pope sir, his lips shall kiss my sister's soft lip: and thine, the tough lips of this: nay sir, I do but show you that I have a tool; do you heat saint Dennis, but that we both stand upon the narrow bridge of honour, I should cut your throat now, for pure love you bear to my sister, but that I know you would set out a throat.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Wilt thou not stab the peasant,
That thus dishonours both thyself and me?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Saint mark set his marks upon me then: stab? I'll have my shins broken, ere I'll scratch so much as the skin off, a the law of arms: shall I make a Frenchman cry o, before the fall of the leaf? not I by the cross of this, Dandyprat.

sp.speaker: Dan
sp.l: If you will sir you shall coin me into a shilling.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I shall lay too heavy a cross upon thee then.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Is this a time to jest? Boy call my servants.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: Gentlemen to the dresser.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You rogue what dresser? cease on Fontenell,
And lodge him in a dungeon presently.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: He steps upon his death that stirs a foot.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That shall I try, as in the field before
I made thee stoop, so here I'll make thee bow.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Thou play'dst the soldier then, the villain now.
sp.stage: Camillo and his men set upon him, get him down and disweapon him, and hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Treacherous Italians.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.l: Hale him to a dungeon,
There if your thoughts can apprehend the form,
Of Violetta; dote on her rare feature,
Or if your proud flesh with a sparing diet,
Can still retain her swelling spritefulness;
Then court (Instead of her) the croaking vermin,
That people, that most solitary vault.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But sirrah Camillo, wilt thou play the wise and venerable bearded master Constable, and commit him indeed, because he would be meddling in thy precinct and will not put off the cap of his love to the brown-bill of thy desires? Well, thou hast given the law of arms a broken pate already, therefore if thou wilt needs turn broker, and be a cutthroat too, do: for my part, I'll go get a sweet ball, and wash my hands of it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Away with him, my life shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: To prison must I then? well, I will go,
And with a light-winged spirit insult o'er woe,
For in the darkest hell on earth, I'll find
Her fair idea to content my mind,
Yet France and Italy with blistered tongue,
Shall publish thy dishonour in my wrong
O now how happy wert thou, couldst thou lodge me
Where I could leave to love her?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: By heaven I can.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Thou canst: o happy man!
This a kind of new invented law,
First feed the axe, after produce the saw,
Her heart no doubt will thy affections feel;
For thou'lt plead sighs in blood, and tears in steel.
Boy tell my love, her love thus sighing spoke:
I'll veil my crest to death, for her dear sake.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Boy: what boy is that?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is't you sir Pandarus, the broking knight of Troy, are your two legs the pair of trestles, for the Frenchman to get up upon my sister?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By the nine worthies, worthy gallants not I; I a gentleman for conveyance? I sir Pandarus? would Troy then were in my breeches, and I burned worse than poor Troy: sweet signior you know, I know, and all Venice knows, that my mistress scorns double dealing with her heels.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
With her heels? O here's a sure pocket dag, and my sister shoots him off snipsnap at her pleasure. Sirrah Mephistopheles,
did not you bring letters from my sister to the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.l: Signior no.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Did not you fetch him out of the tennis court?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No point per mafoy, you see I have many tongues speak for me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Did not he follow your crack-ship, at a beck given?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.l: Ita, true, certes, he spied, and I spitting thus, went thus.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: But were stayed thus.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You hold a my side, and therefore I must needs stick to you, 'tis true: I going, he followed; and following, fingered me, just as your worship does now: but I struggled and straggled, and wraggled and wraggle, and at last cried vale valete, as I do now, with this fragment of a rhyme:
sp.l: My lady is grossly fallen in love, and yet her waste is slender,
Had I not slipped away, you would have made my buttocks tender.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Shall Doyt and I play the bloodhounds and after him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, let him run.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Not for this wager of my sister's love, run; away Dandyprat, catch truepenny, and hold him, thyself shall pass more currant.

sp.speaker: Da
sp.l: I fly sir, your dandiprat is as light as a clipt angel.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nay god's lid after him Camillo, reply not but away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Content, you know where to meet:

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: For I know that the only way to win a wench, is not to woe her: the only way to have her fast, is to have her loose: the only way to triumph over her, is to make her fall; and the way to make her fall, —

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: Is to throw her down.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Are you so cunning sir?

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: O ▪ lord sir; and have so perfect a master.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well sir, you know the gentlewoman that dwells in the midst of saint marks street.

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.l: Midst of s. Marks street sir?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A pox on you; the flea-bitten faced lady.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.p: O sir, the freckle check madonna, I know her signior, as well —

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not as I do, I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.p: No sir I de be loath to have such inward acquaintance with her as you have.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well sir slip go presently to her, and from me deliver to her own white hands, Fontinell's picture.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.p: Indeed sir she loves to have her chamber hung with the pictures of men.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: She does, le keep my sister's eyes and his painted face asunder; tell her besides, the mask holds and this the night, and nine the hour; say we are all for her away.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: And she's for you all, were you an army.
sp.stage: Enter Imperia the courtesan, two maids Trivia and Simperina, with perfumes.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie, fie, by the light oath of my fan, the weather is exceeding tedious and faint: Trivia, Simperina, stir, stir, stir, one of you open the casements, tother take a ventoy and gently cool my face: fie, I ha' such an exceeding high colour, I so sweat; Simperina, dost hear? prithee be more compendious: why Simperina!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Here madam.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Press down my ruff before; away, fie, how thou blowest upon me, thy breath (God's me) thy breath, fie, fie, fie, fie, it takes off all the painting and colour from my cheek: in good faith I care not if I go and be sick presently; heigh ho, my head so aches with carrying this bodkin: in troth I'll try if I can be sick.

sp.speaker: Triu.
sp.l: Nam good sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You know a company of gallants will be here at night be not out of temper sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
In good troth if I be not sick I must be melancholy then: this same gown never comes on but I am so melancholy, and so heart-burnt: 'tis a strange garment, I warrant Simperina the
foolish tailor that made it, was troubled with the stitch, when he composed it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That's very likely madam, but it makes you have o a most incony body.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no no, no by saint mark the waste is not long enough, (For I love a long and tedious waste, besides, I have a most ungodly middle in it; and fie, fie, fie, fie, it makes me bend i'th back: o let me have some music.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That's not the fault in your gown madam, but of your bawdy.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Fa la la fa la la, indeed the bending of the back is the fault of the body la, la, la, la; fa la la, fa la la, la la lah.

sp.speaker: Trm.
sp.l: O rich!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O rare!

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no, no no, no: 'tis slight and common all that I do, prithee Simperina do not ingle me; do not flatter me Trivia, I ha' never a cast gown till the next week, fa la la, la la la, fa la la, fa la la etc. This stirring to and fro has done me much good; a song I prithee, I love these French mo●uings; o they are so clean if you tread them true, you shall hit them to a hair; sing, sing, sing some odd and fantastical thing, for I cannot abide these dull and lumpish tunes, the musician stands longer a pricking them then I would do to hear them: no, no no give me your light ones that go nimbly and quick, and are full of changes and carry sweet division; ho prithee sing, stay, stay, stay, here's Hippolito's sonnet, first read it and then sing it.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: In a fair woman what thing is best?
I think a curral lip.
No no you jest,
She has a better thing.
Then 'tis a pretty eye.
Yet 'tis a better thing,
Which more delight does bring.
Then 'tis a cherry cheek.
No, no, you l ye.
Were neither lip, nor cheeks coral, nor cherry eyes,
Were not her swelling breast stuck with strawberries,
Nor had smooth hand, soft skin, white neck, pure eye,
Yet she at this alone your love can tie.
It is, oh 'tis the only joy to men,
The only praise to women; what is't then?
This it is, oh this it is, and in a woman's middle it is placed,
In a most beauteous body, a heart most chaste:
This is the jewel Kings may buy,
If women sell this jewel, women bye.

sp.stage: One knocks within, Frisco answers within.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Who the pox knocks?

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.l: One that will knock thy coxcomb if he do not enter.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: If thou dost not enter, how canst thou knock me?

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.l: Why then I'll knock thee when I do enter.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why then thou shalt not enter, but instead of me knock thy heels.

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: Frisco I am Doyt Hippolito's page:

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: And I am Frisco, squire to a bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: I have a jewel to deliver to thy mistress.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Is't set with precious stones?

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: Thick, thick thick.
sp.stage: Enter Doyt with the picture, and Frisco.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Why enter then thick, thick, thick.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, fie, fie who makes that yawling at door?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.p: Here's signior Hipolito's man (That shall be) come to hang you.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Trivia, strip that villain; Simperina pinch him, slit his wide nose; fie, fie, fie, I'll have you gelded for this lustiness.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And she threatens to geld me unless I be lusty; what shall poor Frisco do?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hang me.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Not I, hang me if you will, and set up my quarters too.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hippolito's boy come to hang me?

sp.speaker: Doy.
sp.p: To hang you with jewels, sweet and gentle; that's Frisco's meaning, and that's my coming.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Keep the door.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: That's my office indeed, I have been your doorkeeper so long, that all the hinges, the spring-locks and the ring, are worn to pieces; how if anybody knock at the door?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Let them enter, fie, fie, fie, fie, fie, his great tongue does so run through my little ears; 'tis more harsh than a yonger brother's courting of a gentlewoman, when he has no crowns, boy?

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: At your service.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: My service? alas alas, thou canst do me small service, did thy master send this painted gentle man to me?

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: This painted gentleman to you.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Well, I will hang his picture up by the walls, till I see his face, and when I see his face, I'll take his picture down: hold it Trivia.

sp.speaker: Triu.
sp.l: It's most sweetly made.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hang him up Simperina.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: It's a most sweet man.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: And does the mask hold? let me see it again.

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.p: If their vizards hold, here you shall see all their blind cheeks; this is the night, nine the hour, and I the lack that gives warning.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: He gives warning mistress, shall I set him out?

sp.speaker: Doyt.
sp.l: You shall not need, I can set out myself.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Flaxen hair, and short too, o that's the French cum! but fie, fie, fie, this flaxen haired men are such pu-lers, and such pidlers, and such chicken-hearts (And yet great quarrellers) that when they court a lady, they are for the better part bound to the peace: no, no, no, no, your black haired man (So he be fair) is your only sweet man, and in any service, the most active: a banquet Trivia;
quick, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Triu.
sp.p: In a twinkling; 'slid my mistress cries like the road-woman: quick quick, quick, buy any rosemary and bays?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: A little face, but a lovely face; fie, fie, fie, no matter what face he make, so the other parts be legitimate, and go upright: stir, stir Simperina, be doing, be doing, quickly; move, move, move.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Most incontinently, move, move, move: o sweet!

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Hey ho, as I live I must love thee, and suck kisses from thy lips; alack that women should fall thus deeply in love, with dumbethings, that have no feeling? but they are women's crosses, and the only way to take them is to take them patiently; heigh ho! set music Frisco.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Music, if thou hast not a hard heart, speak to my mistress.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Say he scorn to marry me, yet he shall stand me in some steed, by being my Ganymede: if he be the most decayed gallant in all Venice, I will myself undo myself, and my whole state to set him up again: though speaking truth would save my life, I will lie to do him pleasure: yet to tell lies may hurt the soul: fie no no, no, souls are things to be trodden under our feet, when we dance after love's pipe; therefore here hang this counterfeit at my bed's feet.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: If he be counterfeit, nail him up upon one of your posts.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: By the moist hand of love I swear, I will be his lottery, and he shall never draw, but it shall be a prize.

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.l: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: Curu.
sp.l: Why 'tis I knave.

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.l: Then knave knock there still.

sp.speaker: Curu.
sp.l: Wilt open door?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Yes when I list I will.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Here's money.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Much:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Here's gold.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Away:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Knave open.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Call to our maids, God night, we are all a slopen.
sp.p: Mistress, if you have ever a pinnace to set out, you may now have it maned and rigged; for signior Curvetto, he that cries, I am an old courtier, but lie close, lie close, when our maids swear he lies as wide as any courtier in Italy.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Do we care how he lies?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Anon, anon, anon, this old hoary red deer, serves himself in at your keyhole.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: What Frisco?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Hark, shall he enter the breach?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie, I wonder what this gurnets head makes here: yet bring him in, he will serve for picking meat; let music play, for I will feign myself to be asleep .

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Three pence, and here's a teston, yet take all,
Coming to jump, we must be prodigal:
Hem, I am an old courtier, and I can lie close;
Put up Frisco, put up, put, up, put up.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Any thing at your hands sir, I will put up, because you seldom pull out any thing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Softly sweet signior Curvetto, for she's fast.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ha, fast? my roba fast? and but young night:
She's wearied, wearied, ah ha, hit I right?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How sir, wearied? marry foh.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Wearied sir? marry muff.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No words, here mouse, no words, no words sweet rose,
I am an hoary courtier, and lie close, lie close, hem:

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: An old hoary courtier? why so has a jowl of ling, and a musty whiting been (Time out of mind) methinks signior, you should not be so old by your face:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I have a good heart knave; and a good heart
Is a good face-maker, I am young, quick, brisk,
I was a reveller in a long stock;
(There's not a gallant now fills such a stock)
Plump hose, pained, stuffed with hair (Hair then was held
The lightest stuffing) a fair codpiece: hoh,
An eel-skin sleeve, lashed here and there with lace,
High collar, lashed again: breech lashed also:
A little simpering ruff, a dapper cloak,
With Spanish buttoned cape: my rapier here,
Gloves like a burgomaster here; hat here,
(Stuck with some ten-groat brooch:) and over all,
A goodly, long thick, abram-coloured beard;
Ho God, ho God, thus did I revel it.
When monsieur Mot lay here ambassador.
But now those beards are gone, our chins are bare;
Our corters now do all against the hair.
I can lie close and see this, but not see,
I am hoary, but not hoary as some be.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hey ho; who's that? Signior Curvetto? by my virginity —

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Hem, no more,
Swear not so deep at this years, men have eyes,
And though the most are fools, some fools are wise.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie, and you meet me thus at half weapon, one must down.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: She for my life.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Somebody shall pay for't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: He for my head.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Do not therefore come over me so with cross blows, no, no, no, I shall be sick, if my speech be stopped: by my virginity I swear: and why may not I swear by that I have not, as well as poor musty soldiers do by their honour: brides, at four and twenty: ha, ha, ha, by their maidenheads: citizens, by their faith, and brokers as they hope to be saved: by my virginity I swear, I dreamed that one brought me a goodly codshead, and in one of the eyes, there stuck ( methought )
the greatest precious stone, the most sparkling diamond: o fie, fie, fie, fie, fie, that diamonds should make women such fools.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A codshead and a diamond, ha, ha, ha,
'Tis common, common, you may dream as well
Of diamonds and of codsheads, where's not one,
As swear by your virginity where's none.
I am that codshead, she has spied my stone,
My diamond: noble wench, but nobler no see;
I am an old courtier, and lie close, lie close.
sp.stage: The cornets sound a lavolta which the maskers are to dance, Camillo, Hippolito, and other gallants, every one save Hippolito, with a lady masked, zanies with coaches enter suddenly: Curuetto offers to depart.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no, no, if you shrink from me I will not love you: stay.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I am conjured, and will keep my circle.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie, by the neat tongue of eloquence, this measure is out of measure, 'tis too hot, too hot, gallants be not ashamed to show your own faces: ladies unapparel your dear beauties: so, so, so, so, here is a banquet; sit, sit, sit signior Curvetto, thrust in among them, soft music there, do, do, do.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I will first salute the men, close with the women, and last sit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But not sit last: a banquet? and have these suckets here? o I have a crew of angels prisoners in my pocket, and none but a good bale of dice can fetch them out: dice ho; come my little lecherous baboon, by saint mark, you shall venture your twenty crowns.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: And have but one.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I swore first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Right, you swore,
But oaths are now like Blurt our constable,
standing for nothing, a mere plot, a trick,
The mask dogged me, I hit it in the nick;
A fetch to get my diamond, my dear stone,
I am a hoary courtier, but lie close, close, close;
I'll play sir.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: But in my tother hose.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Curvetto?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Let him go, I knew what hook would choke him, and therefore baited that for him to nibble upon: an old comb-pecked rascal, that was beaten out a'th cockpit, when I could not stand a hye-lone without I held by a thing, to come crowing among us: hang him lobster; come, the same oath that your foreman took, take all, and sing.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Love is like a lamb, and love is like a lion,
Fly from love, he fights; fight, then does he fly on:
Love is all in fire, and yet is ever freezing,
Love is much in winning, yet is more in losing.
Love is ever sick, and yet is never dying,
Love is ever true, and yet is ever lying.
Love does dote in liking, and is mad in loathing,
Love indeed is any thing, yet indeed is nothing.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Mars armipotent with his court-of-guard, give sharpness to my Toledo, I am beleaguered, o Cupid grant that my blushing prove not a linstock, and give fire too suddenly to the roaring Meg of my desires; most sanguine cheeked ladies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: 'Sfoot how now don Dego; sanguine cheeked? dost think their faces have been at cutlers? out you roaring-tawnyfaced rascal, 'twere a good deed to beat my hilts about's coxcomb, and then make him sanguine cheeked too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay good Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, fie, fie, fie, though I hate his company, I would not have my house to abuse his countenance: no, no, no, be not so
contagious, I will send him hence with a flea in's ear.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Do, or I'll turn him into a flea, and make him skip under some of your petticoats.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Signior Lazarillo:

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Most sweet face you need not hang out your silken tongue as a flag of truce: for I will drop at your feet, ere I draw blood in your chamber; yet I shall hardly drink up this wrong, for your sake I will wipe it out for this time: I would deal with you in secret (So you had a void room) about most deep and serious matters.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I'll send these hence; fie, fie, fie, I am so choked still with this man of gingerbread, and yet I can never be rid of him, but hark Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Good draw the curtains, put out candles, and girls to bed.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Venus, give me suck, from thine own most white and tender dugs, that I may batten in love: dear instrument of many men's delight, are all these women?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: No no, no, they are half men and half women.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: You apprehend too fast, I mean by women, wives: for wives are no maids, nor are maids women: if those unbearded gallants keep the doors of their wedlock, those ladies spend their hours of pastime but ill, (O most rich armful of beauty) but if you can bring all those feamales into one ring, into one private place: I will read a lecture of discipline, to their most great and honourable ears; wherein I will teach them, so to carry their white bodies, either before their husbands or before their lovers, that they shall never fear to have milk thrown in their faces; nor I, wine in mine, when I come to sit upon them in courtesy.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: That were excellent, I'll have them all here at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I will show them all the tricks and garbs of Spanish dames, I will study for apt and legant phrase to tickle them with; and when my device is ready I will come: will you inspire into your most divine spirits, the most divine soul of tobacco?

sp.speaker: Im.
sp.p: No, no, no; fie, fie, fie, I should be choked up if your pipe should kiss my underlip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Hence forth, most deep stamp of feminine perfection, my pipe shall not be drawn before you, but in secret.
sp.stage: Enter Hippolito and the rest of the maskers, as before dancing: Hippolito takes Imperia, exeunt.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Lament my case since thou canst not provoke,
Her nose to smell, love fill thine own with smoke.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: The wooden picture you sent her, hath set her on fire; and she desires you as you pity the case of a poor desperate gentlewoman, to serve that Monsieur in at supper to her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: The Frenchman, saint Dennis, let her carve him up: stay, here's Camillo; now my fool in fashion, my sage idiot, up with this brims, down with this devil (Melancholy) are you decayed concupiscentious inamorato? news, news, Imperia dotes on Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What comfort speaks her love to my sick heart?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Marry this sir; here's a yellowhammer flew to me with thy water, and I cast it, and find, that his mistress being given to this new falling-sickness, will cure thee: the Frenchman you see has a soft marmalade heart, and shall no sooner feel Imperia's liquorish desire to lick at him, but straight he'll stick the brooch of her longing in it: then sir, may you sir, come upon my sister sir, with a fresh charge sir; sa, sa, sa, sa, once giving back, and thrice coming forward, she yield and the town of breast is taken.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This hath some taste of hope, is that the Mercury
Who brings you notice of his mistress love?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
I may be her Mercury, for my running of errands; but
troth is sir, I am Cerberus, for I am porter to hell.

sp.speaker: Cam
sp.l: Then Cerberus play thy part, here, search that hell,
There find, and bring forth that false Fontinell,
If I can win his strayed thoughts to retire,
From her encountered eyes, whom I have singled
In Hymen's holy battle: he shall pass
From hence to France, in company and guard
Of mine own heart: he comes Hipolito.
Still looks he like a lover, poor gentleman,
Love is the minds strong physic, and the pill,
That leaves the heart sick, and o'erturns the will.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: O happy persecution I embrace thee
With an unfettered soul; so sweet a thing
Is it to sigh upon the rack of love,
Where each calamity is groaning: witness
Of the poor martyr's faith: I never heard
Of any true affection, but was nipped
With care; that (Like the caterpillar) eats
The leaves off the springs sweetest book, (The rose)
„ love bred on earth, is often nursed in hell.
„ by rote it reads woe, ere it learn to spell.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Good morrow French lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Bonjour monsieur.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: To your secure and more than happy self,
I tender thanks, for you have honoured me;
You are my jailor, and have penned me up,
Lest the poor fly (Your prisoner) should alight
Upon your mistress lip; and thence derive,
The dimpled print of an infective touch.
Thou secure tyrant, (Yet unhappy lover)
Couldst thou chain mountains to my captive feet,
Yet Violetta's heart and mine should meet.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Hark swaggerer, there's a little dapple-coloured rascal: ho
a bona roba; her name's Imperia, a gentlewoman by my faith of an ancient house, and has goodly rends, and comings in of her own, and this ape would fain have thee chained to her in the holy state: sirrah, she's fallen in love with thy picture, yes faith too her, woo her, and win her: leave my sister, and thy ransom's paid; all's paid gentlemen; byth' lord Imperia is as good a girl as any is in Venice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Upon mine honour Fontinell 'tis true,
The lady dotes on thy perfections,
Therefore resign my Violetta's heart,
To me the lord of it: and I will send thee —

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: O whether, to damnation? wilt thou not?
Thinkst thou the purity of my true soul
Can taste your leprous counsel? no, I defy you,
Incestancie dwell on his riveled brow,
That weds for dirt; or on thin-forced heart,
That lags in rearward of his father's charge,
When to some negro-gelderling he's clogged,
By the injunction of a golden fee:
When I call back my vows to Violetta,
May I then slip into an obscure grave,
Whose mould (Unpressed with stony monument)
Dwelling in open air, may drink the tears
Of the inconstant clouds to rot me soon,
Out of my private linen sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ay, is this your settled resolution?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: By my love's best divinity it is.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Then bear him to his prison back again,
This tune must alter ere thy lodging mend,
To death fond Frenchman, thy slight love doth tend.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: Then constant heart, thy fate with joy pursue,
Draw wonder to thy death expiring true.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: After him frisco, enforce thy mistress's passion, thou shalt have access to him, to bring him love-tokens: if they prevail not, yet thou shalt still be in presence, be't but to spite him: in honest Frisco.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: I'll vex him to the heart sir, fear not me,
Yet here's a trick perchance may set him free.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Come, wilt thou goelaugh, and lie down? now sure there be some rebels in thy belly, for thine eyes do nothing but watch and ward, thou'st not slept these three nights.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas how can I? he that truly loves
Burns out the day in idle fantasies,
And when the lamb bleating, doth bid goodnight
Unto the closing day; then tears begin
To keep quick time, unto the owl, whose voice
Shrieks, like the bellman in the lover's ears:
Love's eye the jewel of sleep, o seldom wears!
The early lark is wakened from her bed,
Being only by love's plaints disquieted,
And singing in the morning's ear, she weeps
(Being deep in love) at lovers broken sleeps:
But say a golden slumber chance to tie,
With silken strings the cover of love's eye:
Then dreams (Magician-like) mocking present
Pleasures, whose fading, leaves more discontent.
Have you these golden charms?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We have my lord.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Bestow them sweetly; think a lover's heart
Dwells in each instrument and let it melt
In weeping strains: yonder direct your faces,
That the soft summons of a frightless parley,
May creep into the casement: so, begin;
Music speak movingly, assume my part,
For thou must now plead to a stony heart.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Pity, pity, pity,
Pity, pity, pity,
That word begins that ends a true-love ditty,
your blessed eyes (Like a pair of suns,)
Shine in the sphere of smiling,
Your pretty lips (Like a pair of doves)
Are kisses still compiling.
Mercy hangs upon your brow, like a precious jewel,
Oh let not then,
(Most lovely maid, best to be loved of men:)
Marble, lie upon your heart, that will make you cruel:
Pity, pity, pity,
Pity, pity, pity:
That word begins that ends a true-love ditty.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Who owes this salutation?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thy Camillo.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Is not your shadow there too, my sweet bother?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Here sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I dreamt so: o I am much bound to you,
For you my lord have used my love with honour.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ever with honour.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed you have.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Slight, she means her French garsoon.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: The same, good night, trust me 'tis somewhat late,
And this bleak wind nips dead all idle prate.
I must to bed, good night.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The god of rest,
Play music to thine eyes, whilst on my breast
The furies sit and beat, and keep care waking.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You will not leave my friend in this poor taking:

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yes by the velvet brow of darkness.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You scurvy tit: 'sfoot, scurvy anything,
sp.p: Do you hear Susanna: you, punk, if I geld not your musk-cat; I'll do't by Jesu; let's go Camillo.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: Nay but pure swaggerer, ruffian; do you think
To fright me with your bugbear threats? go by;
Hark tosspot in your ear, the frenchman's mine,
And by these hands I'll have him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Rareroage! fine!

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: He is my prisoner, (By a deed of gift)
Therefore Camillo you have wronged me much,
To wrong my prisoner: by my troth I love him,
The rather for the baseness he endures,
For my unworthy self: I'll tell you what;
Release him, let him plead your love for you;
I love a life to hear a man speak French,
Of his complexion: I would undergo
The instruction of that language rather far,
Than be two weeks unmarried (By my life)
Because I'll speak true French, I'll be his wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O scorn to my chaste love, burst heart.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Swounds hold.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Come (Gentle friends) tie your most solemn tunes,
By silver strings unto a leaden pace;
False fair, enjoy thy base-beloved: adieu,
He's far less noble, and shall prove less true.
sp.stage: Enter Truepenny above with a letter.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Lady Imperia (The courtesans zany) hath brought you this letter, from the poor gentleman in the deep dungeon, but would not stay till he had an answer.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Her groom employed by Fontinell? O strange!
I wonder how he got access to him:
I'll read, and (Reading) my poor heart shall ache,
„ true-love is jealous, fears the best love shake.
sp.p: Meet me at the end of the old chapel, next saint Lorenzo's monastery, furnish your company with a friar, that there he may consummate our holy vows, till midnight: farewell.
sp.l: Hath he got opportunity to scape?
O happy period of our separation,
Blessed night, wrap Cinthia in a sable sheet:
That fearful lovers may securely meet.
sp.stage: Enter Frisco in Fontinell's apparel, Fontinell making himself ready in frisco's: they enter suddenly and in fear.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Play you my part bravely; you must look like a slave, and you shall see, I'll counterfeit the Frenchman most knavishly; my mistress (For your sake) charged me on her blessing to fall to these shifts; I left her at cards, she'll sit up till you come, because she'll have you play a game at noddy; you'll to her presently:

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: I will upon mine honour.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I think she does not greatly care whether you fall to her upon your honour, or no: so, all's fit, tell my lady that I go in a suit of durance for her sake; that's your way, and this pithole's mine; if I can scape hence, why so; if not, he that's hanged. is nearer to heaven by half a score steps then he that dies in a bed, and so adieu monsieur.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: Farewell dear trusty slave; shall I profane
This temple with an idol of strange love?
When I do so let me dissolve in fire;
Yet one day will I see this dame, whose heart
Talks off my misery, I'll not be so rude,
To pay her kindness with ingratitude.
sp.stage: Enter Violetta and a friar apace.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: My dearest Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: My Violetta, o God!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O God!

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Where is this reverend friar?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Here, over joyed, young man.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: How didst thou scape?
How came Imperia's man?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: No more of that.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: When did Imperia? —

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Questions now are thieves,
and lies in ambush to surprise our joys,
My most happy stars shine still, shine on,
Away, come, love beset, had need be gone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I must not stay thou sayest:

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: God's me, away.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Buss, buss, again; here's sixpence; buss again,
Farewell, I must not stay then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Foh.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Farewell;
At ten o'clock thou sayest, and ring a bell
Which thou wilt hang out at this window.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Lord I she'll hear this fiddling.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No, close on my word:
Farewell just ten o'clock , I shall come in,
Remember to let down the cord; just ten
Thou'lt open mouse? pray God thou dost, amen, amen, amen,
I am an old courtier wench but I can spy
A young duck: close mum; ten; close, 'tis not I.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Mistress, sweet ladies.
sp.stage: Enter Imperia and ladies, with table books.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Is his old rotten aquavitae bottle stopped up? is he gone? fie, fie, fie, fie, he so smells of ale and onions, and rosa-solis, fie; bolt the door, stop the keyhole lest his breath peep in, burn some perfume: I do not love to handle these dried stockfishes that ask so much tawing, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: Nor I, trust me lady, fie!

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no no no, stools and cushions, low stools, low stools, sit, sit, sit, round ladies round; so, so, so, so let, our sweet beauties be spread to the full and most moving advantage, for we are fallen into his hands, who they say, has an a b c, for the sticking in of the least white pin in any part of the body.

sp.speaker: 2 lady.
sp.p:
Madam Imperia, what stuff is he like to draw out
before us?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, 'tis Greek to me, 'tis Greek to me, I never had remnant of his Spanish leather learning: here he comes, your ears may now fit themselves out of the whole piece.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I do first deliver to your most skreete, and long-fingered hands, this head (Or top of all the members) bare and uncombed, to show how deeply I stand in reverence of your naked female beauties. Bright and unclipped angels, if I were to make a discovery of any new-found land (As Virginia or so) to ladies and courtiers, my speech should hoist up sails, fit to bear up such lofty and well rigged vessels: but because I am to deal only with the civil city matron; I will not lay upon your blushing and delicate cheek, any other colours, than such as will give luster to your chitty faces, in and to that purpose, our thesis is taken out of that most plentiful, but most precious book: entitled, the economical cornucopia.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: The what?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: The economical cornucopia; thus,
Wise is that wife, who (With apt wit) complains,
That she's kept under, yet rules all the reins.

sp.speaker: 2 lady.
sp.l: O again sweet signior? Complains.
That she's kept under? what follows?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yet rules all the reins:
Wife is that wife, who (With apt wit) complains,
That she's kept under, yet rules all the reins.
sp.p: Most pure and refined plants of nature, I will not (As this distinction enticeth) take up the parts as they lie here in order: as first, to touch your wisdom, it were folly: next, your complaining, 'tis too common: thirdly, your keeping under, 'tis above my capacity: and lastly, the reins in your own hands, that is the a-per-se of all, the very cream of all, and therefore how to skim off that only, only listen: a wife wise, no matter: apt wit; no matter: complaining, no matter: kept under, no great matter: but to rule the roast, is the matter.

sp.speaker: 4 lady.
sp.l: That ruling of the roast goes with me.

sp.speaker: 4 lady.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: 5 lady.
sp.l: And me, I'll have a cut of that roast.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Since then, a woman's only desire is to have the reins in her own white hand; your chief practice (The very same day that you are wived) must be to get hold of these reins, and being fully gotten, or wound about; yet to complain (With apt wit) as though you had them not.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: How shall we know signior, when we have them all or not?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I will furnish your capable understandings, out of my poor Spanish store, with the chief implements, and their appurtenances: observe, it shall be your first and finest praise, to sing the note of every new fashion, at first sight; and (If you can) to stretch that note above eela.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: The more you pinch your servants bellies for this, the smoother will the fashion sit on your back: but if your good man, like not this music, (As being too full of crochets) your only way is, to learn to play upon the virginals, and so nail his ears to your sweet humours: if this be out of time too, yet your labour will quit the cost; for by this means your secret friend may have free and open access to you, under the colour of pricking you lessons: now, because you may tie your husband's love in most sweet knots, you shall never give over labouring, till out of his purse you have digged a garden: and that garden must stand a pretty distance from the city; for by repairing thither, much good fruit may be grafted.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: Mark that.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p:
Then (In the afternoon ) when you address your sweet perfumed body, to walk to this garden, there to gather a nosegay, sops-in-wine, cowslips, columbines, hearts-ease; etc. The first principle to learn is, that you stick black patches for the rheum on your delicate blue temples, though there be no room for the rheum; black patches are comely in most women, and being well fastened, draw men's eyes to shoot glances at you:
next, your ruff must stand in print, and for that purpose, get poking sticks with fair and long handles, lest they scorch your lily sweating hands: than your hat with a little brim (If you have a little face) if otherwise, otherwise. Besides, you must play the wag with your wanton fan; have your dog (Called pearl or Min, or why ask you? or any other pretty name) dance along by you: your embroidered muff before you, on your ravishing hands; but take heed who thrusts his fingers into your fur.

sp.speaker: 2 lady.
sp.l: We'll watch for that.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Once a quarter take state upon you, and be chick; being chick, (Thus politicly) lie at your garden; your lip-sworn servant may there visit you as a physician: where otherwise, (If you languish at home) be sure your husband will look to your water: this thickness may be increased, with giving out that you breed young bones; and to stick flesh upon those bones, it shall not be amiss, if you long for peascods, at ten groats the cod; and for cherries at a crown the cherry.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: O dear tutor!

sp.speaker: 2 lady.
sp.l: Interrupt him not.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: If while this pleasing fit of thickness hold you, you be invited forth to supper, whimper and seem unwilling to go; but if your good man (Bestowing the sweet duck, and kiss upon your moist lip) entreat, go: marry my counsel is, you eat little at table, because it may be said of you, you are no cormorant; yet at your coming home you may counterfeit a qualm, and so devour a posset: your husband need not have his nose in that posset: no, trust your chambermaid only in this; and scarcely her, for you cannot be too careful into whose hands you commit your secrets.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: That's certain.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p:
If you have daughters capable, marry them by no means to chittizens, but choose for them some smooth chinned curled-headed gentleman; for gentlemen will lift up your daughters to their own content: and to make these curled-pated gallants come off the more roundly, make your husband go to the herald for arms; and let it be your daily care, that
he have a fair and comely crest; yea, go all the ways yourselves you can to be made ladies, especially if (Without danger to his person, or for love or money) you can procure your husband to be dubbed: the goddess of memory lock up these jewels which I have bestowed upon you, in your sweet brains: let these be the rules to square out your life by, though you ne'er go level, but tread you shoes awry: if you can get these reins into your lily hand you shall need no coaches, but may drive your husbands: put it down, and according to that wise saying of you, be saints in the church, angels in the street, devils in the kitchen, and apes in your bed; upon which, leaving you tumbling; pardon me that thus abruptly and openly I take you all up.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: You have got so far into our books signior, that you cannot scape without a pardon here, if you take us up never so snappishly.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Music there to close our stomachs: how do you like him madonna?

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.p: O trust me, I like him most profoundly: why, he's able to put down twenty such as I am.

sp.speaker: 3 lady.
sp.p: Let them build upon that; nay more, we'll henceforth never go to a cunning woman, since men can teach us our lerrie.

sp.speaker: 4 La.
sp.p: We are all fools to him, and our husbands (If we can hold these reins fast) shall be fools to us.

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.p: If we can keep but this bias wenches, our good men may perchance once in a month, get a foregame of us: but if they win a rubbers, let them throw their caps at it.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no, no, dear features, hold their noses to the grindstone and they're gone; thanks worthy signior: fie, fie, fie, you stand bare too long: come bright mirrors, will you withdraw into a gallery, and taste a slight banquet?

sp.speaker: 1 lad.
sp.p: We shall cloy ourselves with sweets, my sweet madonna.

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.l: Troth I will not madonna Imperia.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
No, no, no, fie, fie, fie, signior Lazarillo, either be you
our foreman, or else put in these ladies (At your discreation) unto the gallery and cut of this striving.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It shall be my office, my fees being (As they pass) to take toll of their alabaster hands.
Imperia stays. Admired creature, I summon you to a parley, you remember this is the night?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So, so, so, I do remember; here is a key, that is your chamber; lights Simperina: about twelve o'clock you shall take my beauty prisoner; fie, fie, fie, how I blush? at 12. o'clock .

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Rich argosy of all golden pleasure.

sp.speaker: Im.
sp.p: No, no, no, put up, put up your joys till anon, I will come by my virginity; but I must tell you one thing, that all my chambers are many nights haunted; with what sprites none can see: but sometimes we hear birds singing; sometimes music playing; sometimes voices laughing, but stir not you, nor be frighted at any thing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By Hercules, if any spirits rise, I will conjure them in their own circles with Toledo. (Ready?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: So, so, so, lights for his chamber: is the trap-door

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: 'Tis set sure.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So, so, so, I will be rid of this broiled red sprat that stinks so in my stomach, fie; I hate him worse, than to have a tailor come a-wooing to me: god's me, the sweet ladies, the banquet, I forget: fie, fie, fie, follow dear signior.
The trap door Simperina.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Signior come away.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Cupid I kiss the nock of thy sweet bow,
A woman makes me yield, Mars could not so.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Just ten? 'tis ten just, that's the fixed hour,
For payment of my love's due fees; that broke:
I forfeit a huge sum of joys: ho love,
I'll keep time just to a minute, ay,
A sweet guide's loss, is a deep penalty.
A night's so rich a venture to taste wrack,
Would make a lover bankrupt, break his back:
no, if to sit up late, early to rise,
Or, if this goldfinch, that with sweet notes flies,
And wakes the dull eye even of a puritan;
Can work, than wenches curvetto is the man;
I am not young, yet have I youthful tricks,
Which peering day must not see; no, close, close:
Old courtier, perilous fellow; I can lie
Hug in your bosom, close; yet none shall spy.
Stay, here's the door, the window; hah, this, this,
Cord? umh? dear cord, thy blessed knot I kiss:
None peeps I hope, night clap thy velvet hand
Upon all eyes, if now my friend thou stand:
I'll hang a jewel at thine ear sweet night,
And here it is, lantern and candlelight.
A peal, a lusty peal, set, ring loves knell,
I'll sweat, but thus I'll bear away the bell.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Signior, who's there, signior Curvetto?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Umh! drowned? Noah's flood? ducked over head and ears?
O sconce! And o sconce! an old soaker, o
I sweat now till I drop, what villains; o?
Punks, punkateeroes, nags, hags, I will ban,
I have caught my bane.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A waterman.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Who rings that scolding peal? (By th'ounce

sp.speaker: Cu
sp.l: I am wringing wet, I am washed; foh, here's rose-water sold
This sconce shall batter down those windows. Bounce:

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What do you mean? why do you beat our doors?
What do you take us for?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: You're all damned whores.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Signior Curvetto?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Signior coxcomb, no;

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What makes you be so hot?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: You lie, I am cool,
I am an old courtier, but stinking fool, foh!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: God's my life what have you done? you are in a sweet pickle if you pulled at this rope:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Hang thyself in't, and I'll pull once again.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mary Muff, will you up and ride, you're mine elder: by my pure maidenhead here's a jest: why this was a waterwork to drown a rat that uses to creep in at this window.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Fire on your waterworks, catch a drowned rat:
That's me, I have it godamercy head,
Rat? me; I smell a rat, I strike it dead.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You smell a sodden sheep shed; a rat? I a rat, and you will not believe me marry foh; I have been believed of your betters, marry snick up.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Simp, nay sweet Simp, open again, why Simperina?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Go from my window go, go from, etc. away, go by old Jeronimo; nay and you shrink i'th wetting, walk, walk, walk.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy, if the bowl were set,
To drown a rat; I shrink not am not wet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A rat by this hemp, and you could ha' smelled; hark you, here's the bell, ting, ting, ting; would the clapper were in my belly, if I am not mad at your foppery; I could scratch, fie, fie, fie, fie, fie, (As my mistress says) but go, hie you home; shift you, come back presently; here you shall find a ladder of cords, climb up, I'll receive you, my mistress lies alone, she's yours, away.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: O Simp!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay scud, you know what you promised me: I shall have simple yawling for this, be gone and mum.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Thanks, mum dear girl; I am gone, 'twas for a rat,
A rat upon my life; thou shalt have gifts,
I love thee though thou puts me to my shifts:
I know I could be overreached by none,
A paulons head, lie close, lie close, I am gone.
sp.stage: Music suddenly plays, and birds sing: enter Lazarillo bare headed in his shirt: a pair of pantaples on, a rapier in his hand and a tobacco pipe: he seems amazed, and walks so up and down. A song presently within.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Saint Jaques and the seven deadly sins (That is, the seven wise masters of the world) pardon me for this night, I will kill the devil.

sp.speaker: Witbin.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou prince of blackamoors, thou shalt have small cause to laugh, if I run thee through: this chamber is haunted, would I had not been brought a-bed in it, or else were well delivered: for my heart tells me 'tis no good luck, to have any thing to do with the devil, he's a paltry merchant.

lg.head: A song within.
lg.l: Midnight's bell goes ting, ting, ting, ting, ting,
Than dogs do howl, and not a bird does sing:
But the nightingale, and she cries twit, twit, twit, twit:
Owls then on every bow do sit.
