Ravens croak on chimney's tops,
The cricket in the chamber hops:
And the cat's cry mew, mew, mew,
The nibbling mouse is not asleep
But he goes, peep, peep, peep, peep, peep,
And the cat's cries, mew, mew mew,
And still the cat's cries mew, mew, mew.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I shall be moused by puss-cats: but I had rather die a dog's death; they have nine lives (A piece like a woman) and they will make it up ten lives, if they and I fall a scratching: bright Helena of this house, would thy Troy were a fire, for I am a cold; or else would I had the Greeks wooden Curtall, to ride away: most ambrosian-lipped creature, come away quickly, for this night's lodging lies cold at my heart.
The Spanish pavin: I thought the devil could not understand Spanish: but since thou art my countryman, o thou tawny satin, I will dance after thy pipe.
sp.l: He dances the Spanish pavin.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Ho sweet devil, ho thou wilt make any man weary of thee, though he deal with thee in his shirt,
sp.l: Sweet beauty; she'll not come, I'll fall to sleep,
And dream of her, love-dreams are never too deep.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Ho, ho, Frisco, madonna, I am in hell, but here is no fire; hell fire is all put out; what ho? so ho ho? I shall be drowned; I beseech thee, dear Frisco, raise Blurt the constable, or some scavenger, to come and make clean these kennels of hell, for they stink so, that I shall cast away my precious self.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Is he down frisco?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He's down, he cries out he's in hell, it's heaven to me to have him cry so.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, let him lie, and get all to bed.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Not all, I have fatting knavery in hand,
He cries he's damned in hell; the next shall cry,
He's climbing up to heaven, and here's the gin:
One woodcock stain, I'll have his brother in.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Brisk as a capering tailor; I was washed,
But did they shave me? no, I am too wise;
Lie close i'th bosom of their knaveries,
I am an old hoary courtier, and strike dead:
I hit my marks: ware, ware, a perilous head.
Cast, I must find a ladder made of ropes,
Ladder and rope, what follow? hanging;
But where? ah ha, there does the riddle lie.
I have scaped drowning; but, but, but, I hope,
I shall not scape the ladder and the rope.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Yonder's a light master Constable.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Peace woodcock the sconce approaches.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Whew:

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Ay, whistling? Slubber jog the watch, and give the lantern a flap.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Whew, symp, Symperina?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Signior Curvetto here's the ladder, I watch to do you a good turn, I am Frisco, is not Blurt abroad and his billmen?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No matter if they be, I hear none nigh:
I will snug close; out goes my candle's eye,
My sconce takes this in snuff, all's one I care not.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Why when?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I come, close, close, hold rope and spare not.

sp.speaker: Slu.
sp.l: Now the candle's out.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Frisco, light, light, my foot is slipped, call help:

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.p: Help, help, help, thieves, thieves, help, thieves, etc.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Thieves, where? follow close: slubber the lantern, hold; I charge you in the Duke's name stand: sirrah, you're like to hang for this: down with him.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Master Blurt, master Constable, here's his ladder, he comes to rob my mistress, I have been scared out of my wits, above seven times by him, and it's forty to one, if ever they come in again, I lay felony to his charge.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Felony? you coney-catching slave.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Coney-catching will bear an action; I'll coney-catch you for this; if I can find our key I will aid you: master Blurt, if not, look to him, as you will answer it upon your deathbed.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A Venetian gentleman.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Woodcock, how dost thou woodcock?

sp.speaker: Wod.
sp.l: Thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Woodcock, you are of our side now, and therefore your acquaintance cannot serve, and you were a gentleman of velvet I would commit you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Why, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: What am I sir? do not you know this staff? I am sir the Duke's own image; at this time the Duke's tongue (For fault of a better) lies in my mouth; I am constable sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Constable, and commit me? marry Blurt master Constable.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: It's folly to strive,

sp.speaker: Blurt.
sp.p: I say away with him, I'll Blurt you, I'll teach you to stand covered to authority; your hoary head shall be knocked when this staff is in place.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I but master Constable —

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: No, pardon me, you abuse the Duke, in me that am his cipher, I say away with him; Gulch, away with him; woodcock, keep you with me, I will be known for more than Blurt.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Thou honest fellow (The man in the moon) I beseech thee set fire on thy bush of thorns, to light and warm me, for I am dung wet: I fell like Lucifer I think into hell, and am crawled out, but in worse pickle than my lean pilchard: here about is the hothouse of my love, ho, ho? why ho there?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Who's that? what devil stands hohing at my door so late?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I beseech thee Frisco take in Lazarillo's ghost.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Lazarillo's ghost? haunt me not I charge thee, I know thee not, I am in a dream of a dry-summer, therefore appear not to me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is not this the mansion of the cherry-lipped madonna Imperia?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Yes, how then? you fly-blown rascal, what art thou?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Lazarilla de Tormes: sweet blood, I have a poor Spanish suit, depending in your house; let me enter most precious Frisco, the mistress of this mansion is my beautiful hostess.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: How? you turpentine pill, my wife your hostess? away you Spanish vermin.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I beseech thee (Most pitiful Frisco) allow my lamentation.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And you lament here, I'll stone you with brickbats, I am asleep .

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My slop and mandilion lie at thy mercy (Fine Frisco) I beseech thee let not my case be thine, I must and will lament.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Must you? I'll wash off your tears; away you hogs-face.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou hast soused my poor hogsface: oh Frisco, thou art a scurvy doctor, to cast my water no better; it is most rammish urine, Mars shall not save thee, I will make a brown toast of thy heart, and drink it in a pot of thy strong blood.
sp.stage: Enter Blurt and all his watch.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Such fellows must be taken down, stand: what white thing is yonder?

sp.speaker: Slub.
sp.l: Who goes there? come before the constable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My dear host Blurt:

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: You have blurted fair, I am by my office to examine you, where you have spent these two nights?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Most big Blurt, I answer thy great authority, that I have been in hell, and am scratched to death with puss-cats.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Do you run a'th score at an officer's house, and then run above twelve score off?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I did not run my sweet-faced Blurt; the Spanish fleet is bringing gold enough to discharge all, from the Indies: lodge
me most pitiful billman.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Marry and will: I am (In the Duke's name) to charge you with despicious of felony: and burglary is committed this night, and we are to reprehend any that we think to be faulty; were not you at madonna freckle-face's house?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Signior sec.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Away with him, clap him up.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Most thundering Blurt do not clap me,
Most thundering Blurt do not clap me.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Master Lazarus, I know you are a sore fellow where you take, and therefore I charge you (In the Duke's name) to go without wrestling, though you be in your shirt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Commendable Blurt.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: The end of my commendations is to commit you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am kin to don Dego the Spanish adelantado.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: If you he kin to don Dego (That was smelled out in Paul's) you pack; your lantedoes nor your lanteeroes cannot serve your turn: I charge you, let me commit you to the tuition. —

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Worshipful Blurt, do not commit me into the hands of dogs.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Dogs?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Master Lazarus, there's not a dog shall bite you, these are true billmen, that fight under the common wealth's flag.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Blurt —

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Blurt me no blurts, I'll teach all Spaniards how to meddle with whores.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Most cunning constable, all Spaniards know that already, I have meddled with none.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Your being in your shirt bewrays you.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I beseech thee most honest Blurt, let not my shirt bewray me.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p:
I say away with him: music, that's in the courtesans; they are about some ungodly act, but I'll play a part in't ere
morning: away with Lazarus.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Come Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Thy kites and thee, for this shall watch in dirt to feed on carrion.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Hence, ptrooh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O base Blurt! O base Blurt! O base Blurt!
sp.stage: Enter Camillo, Hippolito, Virgilio, Asorino, Baptista, Bentivoli Doyt and Dandyprat, all weaponed, their rapiers sheathes in their hands.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: Gentlemen and noble Italians, whom I love best; who know best what wrongs I have stood under: being lay de on by him, who is to thank me for his life, I did bestow him (As the prize of mine honour) upon my love, the most fair Violetta: my love's merit was basely sold to him, by the most false Violetta: not content with this felony, he hath dared to add the sweet theft of ignoble marriage; she's now, nonce but his, and he (Treacherous villain) any ones, but hers; he dotes (My honoured friends) on a painted courtesan, and in scorn of our Italian laws, our family, our revenge, loathes Violetta's bed, for a harlot's bosom: I conjure you therefore, by all the bonds of gentility, that as you have solemnly sworn a most sharp; so let the revenge be most sudden.

sp.speaker: Uir.
sp.l: Be not yourself a bar, to that suddenness, by this protraction.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Away gentlemen, away then.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: As for that light hobby-horse my sister, whose foul name, I will raze out with my poniard; by the honour of my family (Which her lust hath profaned) I swear (And gentlemen be in this, my sworn brothers) I swear that as all Venice does admire her beauty, so all the world shall be amazed at her punishment, follow therefore.

sp.speaker: Uir.
sp.p: Stay, let our resolutions keep together: whether go; we first?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To the strumpet Imperia's.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed, what then?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There to find Fontinell; found, to kill him.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And killed, to hang out his reeking body, at his harlot's window.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And by his body, the strumpets.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And between both, my sisters.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The tragedy is just: on then, begin.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: As you go, every hand pull in a friend, to strengthen us against all opposites: he that has any drop of true Italian blood in him, thus vow (This morning) to shed others, or let out his own; if you consent to this, follow me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Via, away, the treacherous Frenchman dies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: At so, saint mark my pistol, thus death flies.
sp.stage: Enter Fontinell and Imperia arm in arm.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Ah you little effeminate sweet chevalier, why dost thou not get a loose periwig of hair on thy chin, to set thy French face off, by the panting pulse of Venus: thou art welcome a thousand degrees beyond the reach of arithmetic: good, good, good, your lip is moist and moving; it hath the truest French close, even like mapew; la, la, la etc.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Dear lady, o life of love, what sweetness dwells
In love's variety? the soul that plods
In one harsh book of beauty; but repeats
The stale and tedious learning, that hath oft
Faded the senses: when (In reading more)
We glide in new sweets, and are starved with store,
Now by the heart of love, my violet
Is a foul weed (O pure Italian flower!)
She, a black negro, to the white compare,
of this unequalled beauty: oh most accursed!
That I have given her leave to challenge me:
But lady, poison speaks Italian well,
And in a loathed kiss, I'll include her hell.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So, so, so do, do, do, come, come, come; will you condemn the mute rushes to be pressed to death by your sweet body? down, down, down, here, here, here; lean your head upon the lap of my gown; good, good good: oh saint mark! Here is a love-mark able to wear more lady's eyes for jewels then — o! lie still, lie still, I will level a true Venetian kiss over your right shoulder.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Shoot home (Fair mistress) and as that kiss flies,
From lip to lip, wound me with your sharp eyes.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no, no, I'll beat this cherrytree thus, and thus, and thus; and you name wound.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: I will offend so, to be beaten still.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Do, do, do, and if you make any more such lips, when I beat you, by my virginity you shall buss this rod: music: I pray thee be not a puritan. Sister to the rest of the sciences, I knew the time when thou couldst abide handling.
O, fie, fie, fie, forbear, thou art like a puny-barber (New come to the trade) thou pickest our ears too deep: so, so, so, will my sweet prisoner entertain a poor Italian song?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Oh most willingly my dear madonna.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I care not if I persuade my bad voice to wrestle with this music and catch a strain; so, so, so, keep time, keep time, keep time.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Love for such a cherry lip,
Would be glad to pawn his arrows:
Venus here to take a sip,
Would sell her doves and team of sparrow.
But they shall not so,
heigh nonny nonny no:
None but I this lip must owe,
Heigh nonny nonny no.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Your voice does teach the music,

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: Again, dear love.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hey nonny nonny no:
Did Jove see this wanton eye,
Ganymede must wait no longer:
Phoebe here one night did lie,
Would change her face and look much younger.
But they shall not so,
Heigh nonny nonny no:
None but I this lip must owe,
Heigh nonny nonny no.
sp.stage: Enter Frisco, Trivia, and Simperina running.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: O madonna! Mistress! Madona!

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Case up this gentleman, there's rapping at door; and one in a small voice, says, there's Camilla and Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Simp
sp.l: And they will come in.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Upon their deaths they shall, for they seek mine.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: No, no, no, lock the doors fast, Trivia, Simperina, stir.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Come they in shape of devils, this angel by:
I am armed, let them come in; uds foot, they die.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, I will not have thy white body —

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: What ho; madonna?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: O hark! not hurt for the Rialto; go, go, go, put up: by my virginity you shall put up.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Here are Camilla and Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Im.
sp.p:
Into that little room, you are there as safe as in France, or
the low countries.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: O God!

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So, so, so, let them enter; Trivia, Simperina, smooth my gown, tread down the rushes, let them enter; do, do, do, no words pretty darling: la, la, la, heigh nonny nonny no.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Are two men transformed into one woman?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: How now? what motion's this?

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.p: By your leave sweet beauty, pardon my excuse, which under the mask of Camillo's and my brother's names, sought entrance into this house: good sweetness, have you not a property here, improper to your house, my husband?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Ha; your husband here?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Nay be as you seem to be (White dove) without gall.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Gall? your husband? ha, ha, ha; by my ventoy (Yellow lady) you take your mark improper, no, no, no, my sugar-candy mistress) your good man is not here I assure you; here? ha hah.

sp.speaker: Triu. and Sim.
sp.l: Here?

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.l: Much husbands here.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Do not mock me fairest venetian; come, I know he's here: good faith I do not blame him, for your beauty glides over his error; troth I am right glad that you (My country woman) have received the pawn of my affections: you cannot be hard-hearted, loving him, nor hate me, for I love him too: since we both love him, let us not leave him, till we have called home the ill husbandry of a sweet Stragler; prithee (Good wench) use him well.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p:
If he deserve not to be used well (As I'd be loath he should deserve it) I'll engage myself (Dear beauty) to thine honest heart; give me leave to love him, and I'll give him a kind of leave to love thee: I know he here's me; I prithee try mine eyes,
if they know him, that have almost drowned themselves in their own salt water, because they cannot see him: in troth I'll not chide him; if I speak words rougher than soft kisses, my penance shall be to see him kiss thee, yet to hold my peace.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: And that's torment enough, alas poor wench.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She's an ass, by the crown of my maidenhead,
I'd scratch her eyes out, if my man stood in her tables.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: Good partner, lodge me in thy private bed,
Where (In supposed folly) he may end,
Determined sin; thou smilest, I know thou wilt;
What looseness may term dotage (Truly read)
Is love ripe gathered, not soon withered.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Good troth (Pretty wedlock) thou mak'st my little eyes smart, with washing themselves in brine; I keep your cock from his own roost? and mar such a sweet face? and wipe off that dainty red? and make Cupid toll the bell for your lovesick heart no, no, no, if he were Jove's own ingle (Ganymede) fie, fie, fie, I'll none; your chamber-fellow is within, thou shalt enjoy my bed, and thine own pleasure this night: Simperina conduct in this lady; Frisco silence, ha, ha, ha; I am sorry to see a woman so tame a fool; come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Star of Venetian beauty, thanks; o who
Can bear this wrong, and be a woman too?
sp.stage: Enter Camillo, Hippolito, Virgilio and others: the Duke and gentlemen with him: Blurt and his watch on his side, with torches.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are dishonoured, give us way, he dies, he dies.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I charge you by your duties to the state,
And love to gentry, sheath your weapons.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Stand, I charge you put up your naked weapons, and we'll put up our rusty bills.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Up to the hilts, we will in his French body.
My lord, we charge you by the ravished honour
Of an Italian lady: by our wrongs,
By that eternal blot (Which if this slave
Pass free without revenge) like leprosy,
Will run over all the body of our fames;
Give open way to our just wrath, least barred —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Breaking the bonds of honour and of duty;
We cut a passage through you with our swords.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: He that withstands us, run him through.

sp.speaker: Blurt.
sp.p: I charge you i'th Duke's name (Before his own face) to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Keep thou the peace, that hast a peasant's heart.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: Peasant?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Our peace must have her cheeks painted with blood.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away, through —

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Sweet gentlemen: though you have called the Duke's own ghost peasant, for I walk for him i'th night: (Kilderkin and Piss-breech hold out) yet hear me, (Dear bloods) the Duke here for fault of a better and myself; (Cuckoo fly not hence) for fault of a better, are to lay you by the heels, if you go thus with fire and sword; for the Duke is the head, and I Blurt, am the appurtenance: woodcock keep by my side: now sir —

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A plague upon this woodcock; kill the watch.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now in the name of manhood I conjure ye,
Appear in your true shapes; Italians,
You kill your honours more in this revenge,
Than in his murder: stay, stand, here's the house.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Right sir, this is the whore-house, here he calls and sets in his staff.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sheath all your weapons worthy gentlemen,
And by my life I swear, if Fontinell
Have stained the honour of your sister's bed,
The fact being death, I'll pay you his proud head,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Arrest him then before our eyes; and see!
Our fury sleeps.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This honest officer —

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.l: Blurt sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Shall fetch him forth: go sirrah, in our name
Attach the French lord.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.l: Garlic and the rest follow strongly.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O what a scandal were it to a state,
To have a stranger, (And a prisoner)
Murdered by such a troop? Besides, through Venice
Are numbers of his countrymen dispersed;
Whose rage (Meeting with yours) none can prevent
The mischief of a bloody consequent.
sp.stage: Enter Blurt and watch, holding Fontinell and his weapons.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: The Duke is within an inch of your nose, and therefore
I dare play with it, if you put not up; deliver I advise you.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Yield up my weapons and my foe so nigh?
Myself and weapons shall together yield,
Come any one, come all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Kill, kill the Frenchman, kill him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be satisfied my noble countrymen,
I'll trust you with his life, so you will pawn
The faithes of gentlemen, no desperate hand
Shall rob him of it; otherwise, he runs
Upon this dangerous point, that dares appose
His rage 'gainst our authority: French lord,
Yield up this strength, our word shall be your guard.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Who defies death, needs none, he's well prepared.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My honest fellow, with a good defence,
Enter again, fetch out the courtesan,
And all that are within.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: I'll tickle her; it shall ne'er be said that a brown bill looked pale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Frenchman, thou art indebted to our Duke.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thy life, for (But for him) thy soul
Had long ere this hung trembling in the air,
Being frighted from thy bosom with our swords.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: I do not thank your Duke; yet (If you will)
Turn bloody executioners: who dies
For so bright beauty, is a bright sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The beauty you adore so, is profane,
The breach of wedlock (By our law) is death.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Law give me law.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: With all severity.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: In my love's eyes immortal joys do dwell,
She is my heaven; she from me, I am in hell:
Therefore your law, your law:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Make way, she comes.
sp.stage: Enter Blurt leading Imperia, watch with Violetta masked.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Your fie, fie, fie, nor your foh, foh, foh, cannot serve your turn; on must now bear it off with head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now fetch Curvetto, and the Spaniard heather,
Their punishments shall lie under one doom,
What is she masked?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: A punk too; follow fellows, slubber afore:

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: She that is masked, is leader of this mask,
What's here? Bows, bills and guns? noble Camillo,
I am sure you are lord of all this misrule: I pray
For whose sake do you make this swaggering fray?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: For yours, and for your own we come resolved,
To murder him, that poisons your chaste bed;
To take revenge on you, for your false heart:
And (Wanton dame) our wrath here must not sleep,
Your sin being deep'st, your share shall be most deep.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: With pardon of your grace, myself (To you all)
At your own weapons, thus do answer all.
For paying away my heart, that was my own,
Fight not to win that, in good troth 'tis gone,
For my dear loves abusing my chaste bed,
And her sweet theft: alack, you are misled,
This was a plot of mine, only to try
Your love's strange temper; sooth I do not lie.
My Fontinell ne'er dallied in her arms;
She never bound his heart with amorous charms,
My Fontinell ne'er loathed my sweet embrace,
She never drew love's picture by his face;
When he from her white hand would strive to go,
She never cried fie, fie, nor no, no, no.
With prayers and bribes, we hired her (Both) to lie
Under that roof; for this must my love die?
Who dare be so hard hearted? look you, we kiss,
And if he loathe his Violetta; judge by this.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: O sweetest violet; I blush —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good figure,
Wear still that maiden blush, but still be mine.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: I seal myself thine own, with both my hands,
In this true deed of gift: gallants, here stands
This lady's champion, at his foot I'll lie,
That dares touch her: who taints my constancy,
I am no man for him, fight he with her,
And yield, for she's a noble conqueror.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This combat shall not need; for see, ashamed,
Of their rash vows, these gentlemen here break,
This storm; and do with hands, what tongues should speak,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: All friends?
All friends.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Punk you may laugh at this,
Here's tricks, but mouth I'll stop you with a kiss.
sp.stage: Enter Curuetto and Lazarillo, led by Blurt and the watch.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Room, keep all the scabs back, for here comes Lazarus.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O here's our other spirits that walk i'th night,
Signior Curvetto, by complaint from her,
And by your writing here, I reach the depth
Of your offence; they charge your climbing up
To be to rob her: if so, then by law
You are to die unless she marry you.

sp.speaker: Im.
sp.l: Ay, fie fie, fie, I will be burned to ashes first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: How? die? or marry her? then call me daw,
Marry her? she's more common than the law,
For boys to call me ox? no, I am not drunk,
I'll play with her, but (Hang her) wed no punk.
I shall be a hoary courtier then indeed,
And have a perilous head, than I were best.
Lie close, lie close, to hide my forked crest.
No; fie, fie, fie, hang me before the door,
Where I was drowned ere I marry with a whore.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well signior, for we rightly understand,
From your accusers, how you stood her guest,
We pardon you and pass it as a jest:
And for the Spaniard sped so hardly too,
Discharge him Blurt, signior we pardon you.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Sir, he's not to be discharged, nor so to be shot off, I have put him into a new suit, and have entered into him which an action, he owes me two and thirty shillings.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: It is thy honour to have me die in thy debt.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: It would be more honour to thee to pay me before thou diest; twenty shillings of this debt came out of his nose.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Bear witness great Duke, he's paid twenty shillings.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Signior no, you cannot smoke me so; he took twenty shillings of it in a fume, and the rest I charge him with for his lying.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My lying (Most pitiful prince) was abominable.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: He did lie (For the time) as well as any knight of the post did ever lie.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I do here put off thy suit, and appeal; I warn thee to the court of conscience, and will pay thee by two pence a week, which I will rake out of the hot embers of tobacco ashes, and then travail on foot to the Indies for more gold, whose red cheeks I will kiss, and beat thee Blurt if thou watch for me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: There be many of your countrymen in Ireland signior, travail to them.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, I will fall no more into bogs.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sirrah, his debt, ourself will satisfy.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Blurt (My lord dare take your word for as much more.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And since this heat of fury is all spent,
And tragic shapes meet comical event:
Let this bright morning, merrily be crowned
With dances, banquets, and choice musics sound.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
